1. What do you notice? If your notice makes a claim, where in the graph is the evidence to support it?

This graph describes how often young men and women content their parents in a span of a day to a week and in what manner. The responses are split into percentages as well as the two genders and show in what percentage of people each group falls. The 3 methods of communication are texts, calls, and in-person visits with texts being the most common.

2. What do you wonder?

I wonder why women contact their parents significantly more than men as well as why there is such a big difference with the genders in the texting and calling groups but not in the in-person visit groups. 

3. What impact does this have on you and your community?

This impacts my community because I and many of my peers are leaving home soon for college and its vital that we remember to check in on our parents and talk to them now and then.

4. What's going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.

Role shift, today's kids won't let go.
ace_sentences: The graph describes how often young men contact their parents.
The graph describes how often young women contact their parents.
The time span is from a day to a week.
The graph shows percentages for each gender group.
The 3 communication methods are texts and calls and in-person visits.
Texts are the most common communication method.
Women contact their parents more often than men.
I wonder why women contact their parents significantly more than men.
I wonder why the gender difference is big for texts and calls.
I wonder why the gender difference is not big for in-person visits.
Many of my peers will leave home soon for college.
I will leave home soon for college.
It is vital that we remember to check in on our parents.
It is vital that we talk to our parents now and then.
The headline is: Role shift, today's kids won't let go.
